text:
Tories accused of 'spinning the statistics' on homelessness after criticism by watchdog The government faced anger after the UK Statistics Authority assessed its "disappointing" claim that homelessness has halved since 2003   Share   Comments By Dan Bloom 19:44, 21 FEB 2017 News Rough sleeping has more than doubled since 2010, government figures show (Photo: Rex Features)   Share   Comments Get politics   The Tories have been accused of "spinning the statistics" on homelessness after concerns were raised by a national watchdog.
The government faced anger after the UK Statistics Authority assessed its "disappointing" claim that homelessness has halved since 2003.
In fact the claim, made in a December press release and repeated in similar terms at least twice, only applied to the specific definition of "statutory homelessness".
Rough sleeping - which is counted separately - has more than doubled to 4,134 people across England since it began being measured in 2010.
Read More Ed Humpherson, director general for regulation at the UK Statistics Authority, criticised the presentation of the figures after a complaint by Lib Dem peer Baroness Grender.
Theresa May's government was accused of 'spinning the statistics' (Photo: PA) He told her: "We would have expected the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) press briefing issued on 13 December, which stated ‘homelessness is less than half the 2003 peak’, to have explicitly included the statutory homelessness definition.
"This exclusion implies that homelessness has more than halved since 2003 on a much broader basis than is shown by the statutory series.
"This is disappointing, given the emphasis the UK Statistics Authority has placed on DCLG providing a comprehensive picture of homelessness."
Baroness Grender said: "Homelessness is a stain on our nation and unacceptable in Britain today.
"The Government has been caught out playing a numbers game, rather than accepting there is a problem, and getting on with the more important work of finding solutions.
"It is time to stop spinning the statistics, and start solving the problem."
The DCLG declined to comment.
